title: Bike Nation: How Cycling Can Save the World
author: Peter Walker
description: A passionate and persuasive case for the benefits of cycling to create more livable cities and healthier citizens. Walker shows how getting more people on bikes could transform our health, economy, and environment.

reviews.author: The Guardian
reviews.text: A fascinating and comprehensive look at cycling culture and its importance to society.

reviews.author: Cycling Weekly
reviews.text: Essential reading for anyone interested in sustainable urban transportation.

title: Street Fight: Handbook for an Urban Revolution
author: Janette Sadik-Khan
description: Former NYC Transportation Commissioner shares how she transformed New York City's streets, challenging the status quo to create more people-friendly spaces including better bike infrastructure.

reviews.author: The New York Times
reviews.text: A powerful narrative about the transformation of urban spaces.

reviews.author: Urban Design Forum
reviews.text: A must-read for city planners and cycling advocates alike.

title: Mobility Justice: The Politics of Movement in an Age of Extremes
author: Mimi Sheller
description: An exploration of how power and inequality inform the governance and control of movement. The book argues for a new understanding of mobility rights and equity.

reviews.author: Journal of Urban Studies
reviews.text: A groundbreaking work that redefines how we think about mobility and justice.

reviews.author: Transportation Research Board
reviews.text: Innovative and thought-provoking perspectives on transportation equity.

title: Fighting Traffic: The Dawn of the Motor Age in the American City
author: Peter D. Norton
description: A groundbreaking history of how American cities became automobile-dependent, and how citizens fought back against the dominance of cars in urban spaces.

reviews.author: Journal of American History
reviews.text: A revelatory account of the social construction of our car-centered transportation system.

reviews.author: Technology and Culture
reviews.text: Essential reading for understanding how cars came to dominate American cities.

title: Walkable City: How Downtown Can Save America, One Step at a Time
author: Jeff Speck
description: A compelling case for how to make our cities more walkable and why it matters for our health, economy, and environment.

reviews.author: The Boston Globe
reviews.text: Makes an unassailable case that the revival of cities depends on making them walkable for everyone.

reviews.author: The Wall Street Journal
reviews.text: A delightful, insightful, irreverent work that should be read by all urban planners.

title: Cycling Revolution: Global Insights
author: Maria Schmidt
description: An essential overview of cycling movements and infrastructure development across different continents.

reviews.author: Cycling Today
reviews.text: A comprehensive global analysis of cycling trends and solutions.

reviews.author: Urban Mobility Review
reviews.text: Essential reading for understanding worldwide cycling developments.
